div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE PROBLEM OF LOST CHAMPIONSHIPS.
div.p: " Whither have gone the majority of our English championships ? Where are those proofs of prowess which it should be Eng land's proud boast that she is able to retain I —a boast, alas ! she can no longer with fairness maintain. The cup of bitterness, for those who ever aver that in the world of sport England still stands first, must during the past few weeks have been full to overflowing, the culminating point being arrived at in the week that has just passed, when the foreigners triumphed in nearly everything tor which they competed, " so bewails the " Daily Telegraph. " ,
" Briefly, a number of English championships may be located as follows :
Golf in France.
Tennis in America.
Lawn Tennis in Australasia and America. Sculling (professional) in Australia. Rowing in Belgium.
Yachting in America and Germany. Pole-jumping in Sweden.
Swimming in America and Australia.

Thus it is that the pupil has in many instances become more efficient than his master, and England, after imparting her knowledge to those abroad, is hoist with her own petard, and now has to stand quietly by whilst English championships one by one leave their native shores, some for the first time. To the mind at once recurs the question, "Are we deteriorating physically 1 "

A writer who signs himself " Emeritus " frames the following indictment against our youth on the evidence of the last few weeks : " What is the matter with our young men ? It is a question which is in everyone's mouth, and which no one seems able to answer. ' Slackness,' as a generic term for nerveless ness, want of tone, absence of ardour, of keenness, of'go,' has, I believe, been practically invented by our gilded youth—and they are the best examples of it themselves. What do they do with their time ? They do not study harder than they used to do—that much can assuredly be taken for granted. They have not become more serious, more thoughtful, more sedentary in their occupations. They do not cultivate the simple life. It would be useless to find in them brilliant examples of the Non-conformist eon science, either at its best or its worst They are supposed to be athletic, to have no other thoughts but for outdoor exercise or sport. It they are inclined to vaunt themselves on any-things, it is on the fact that they love an existence in the open air, and can do most thing with ease which involve the use of hands and legs. And the melancholy fact is that not even in their chosen pastimes are they beyond a fair second-class level. They are too slack to take pains. Most things are 'above.' Sceptical of things that move the world, sceptical of thought, sceptical of sentiment, sceptical of themselves. They have nof the energy to take in their own darling pursuits, in which, more and more every year, they are being beaten by 'the foreigner.'

The "Pall Mall'' discusses the same subject under the heading, "Are we Degenerate f' and says: "On the whole it may well be doubted whether the British athlete, either amateur or professional, is a worse man than his father before him ; and for our part, we see no shame in being fairly beaten by men whom we only despised in the past because we never thought they would put us to the proof. To our mind it is neither very British nor very sportsmanlike to howl over our national degeneracy merely because other nations can hold their own against us in the sports which we ourselves have taught them."

div.head: Stuggle on Tram Car
div.p: A certain Mon rad Effendi Zouhdi was riding on the step of a car of the Cairo Tramway Company on the Ghizeh line, and on being requested to descend by the conductor a struggle ensued, with the result that Mourad Effendi fell under the car and sustained such severe injuries that it is feared that amputation of both legs will be necessary.

div.head: Coast Cuard Administration.
div.p: The Coast Guard Administration are inviting tenders for the construction of two launches with a length overall of 37 feet, breadth at water line 5 feet 8 inches, depth from underside of keel to gunwale at fore end of well 3 feet 9 inches, and to have a raised turtle deck covering 17 feet of length from the stem, well 14 feet 9 inches long, to be decked over abaft well. Full particulars will lx? found in the ''Journal Officiol" of the 29th inst.

div.head: EGYPTIAN DELTA LIGHT RAILWAYS.
div.p: The ordinary general meeting of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways (Limited) was held on Tuesday last at Winchester House.

Sir Charles Fremantle presided, and stated that for the fust time in the history of the company they were able to make a distribution of the full 5j per cent, on the Preference shares. The earnings for the fourteen weeks from April 1 last were £11,861, or 20 per cent, ahead of those for the same period of the year under review. The fact was that Egypt, in his opinion, continued to make steady progress, but over-speculation had been going on for some years, and the inevitable result had oTurred. Stocks and shares with hardly an exception had become inflated in value, and when realisation became necessary it was proved how fictitious many of these values were. A regular panic arose on this discovery, and the whole list of securities was pressed for sale. Their gross earnings increased over the corresponding period by £31,640, of which rather less than half, viz., 115,35o, was absorbed by increased expenses— the resulting net receipts from the working of the lines being £109,095, or 42.65 ]X?r cent, of their gross receipts. The most marked improvement was shown in their passenger traffic, while their goods traffic also exhibited an increase of 9.1 percent, over that for the previous vear. The chief addition tn their undertaking that was contemplated was the extension of the Helouan branch. From Ilelouan the line would probably be extended southwards for about sixty kilometres as a steam road, and would tap a trad of country adjacent to the Nile, and to the development of which considerable attention was being turned.
Mr. P. W. Carver seconded the adoption of the report, which was carried unanimously.

A resolution authorising the directors to enter into an agreement on behalf of the company with the Egyptian Government for modifying the deed of concession for the Helouan railways and schedule of conditions was unanimously agreed to.

div.head: FINANCIAL CRISIS.
CAIRO'S TROUBLES.
AGREEMENT RE SAHAL.
div.p: London, Tuesday.

The assets of Sahal Brothers and Company of Cairo show £117,000 over the firm's liabilities. The English houses interested have now come to a satisfactory agreement that this firm shall continue its business on the condition that it is carried on under an inspectorship.
To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,—The dangerous nature of the exist ing state of a flail's has been proved to be more than well founded. The press has in most cases brought its influence to bear on the situation with a view of bolstering up matters but it is useless disguising the facts any longer. The situation, instead of getting better is becoming worse and wiseheads are very lugubrious in their prognostications, ami the safest people, who know their liabilities to a penny, and exactly what is expected of them, shake their heads in a doubtful manner when questioned. Well may each disbursement or receipt be earmarked in the most careful business manner and every provision made, but the chain of circulating credits, if the expression may be used, has so many weak links at the present moment that those houses which pull through even comparatively unscathed, deserve every praise, as being soundly conducted houses of the highest order. Complaints are general and there are numberless conservative houses who can and will pull through with honour, and who feel no uneasiness for themselves but several of these firms have been known to remark that the eflect of the present crisis will have a far reaching eflect on Egyptian trade. It has been admitted, however, that there will be a considerable weeding out of the inferior houses which will have a beneficial effect; the remedy is apparently as bad as the disease as this weeding out will take some considerable time and in the meantime the extreme caution manifested by Banks and others is frightening the home people.

Of course a really sound firm can satisfy its Banker or buying house in London of its solvability if given a chance, but viewing the crusade against time drafts and very system of credit in vogue, the most powerful houses find their position assailed by every often ill founded rumours. One can onty say that the situation is bad : it may, and probably will, be worse: surmise is somewhat futile and time will show how this country will emerge from a state of a flairs which happily lias not occurred very often recently. Finally the country is prosperous, the Budget good and the trouble under discussion is confined to commercial circles, so that there is every hope of a rally in a reasonable time, although before that happy solution some will have to go to the wall : a 'rise nian however will take all he hears with a grain of salt.
A Cairene Tradesman.
Cairo, 29th July.
The "Times" in its review of the money market concludes as follows :

Monetary conditions have thus been favourable to the necessary strengthening process, and look like remaining so, though the tendency of the discount market was a shade easier towards the end of the week.

It must be admitted that these ideal conditions have been produced, not by any sudden access of grace into the various members of the monetary body, but by an uncomfortable feeling of uncertainty which checked the demand for bills in spite of easy money. The difficulties of an Egyptian firm bad involved certain embarassments, chiefly in the provinces, which, though widespread enough to prevent serious damage in any particular quarter, would have had inconvenient results if they had matured. After several days' suspense, it has been decitied by those chiefly interested that summary proceedings would be a mistake and that time is to be given for the realization of assets which are expected to meet all liabilities. It. is evident that credits have in many rases been granted recklessly and without sufficient inquiry into the circums tances of those opening them, and this result of over competition ami over trading has brought its reward. It is a variation on the same theme that was performed last autumn in the ease of an American finance paper.

div.head: THE REGENT OF EGYPT.
div.p: The following questions concerning Egypt were asked in Parliament last Tuesday:—
Mr. J. M. Robertson asked the Secretary

for Foreign Affairs whether Boutros Ghali Pasha, the Egyptian Minister for Foreign A flairs, who was the president of the special tribunal which a year ago condemned the villagers of Denshawi, had been appointed to act as Regent of Egypt in Highness the Khedive.
Sir E. Grey: As Boutros Ghali Pasha was the senior Minister when his Highness the Khedive left Egypt, he was appointed, in accordance with precedent, to act as Regent.
Mr Robertson : Will the appointment be reconsidered in view of the position occupied by Boutros Ghali Pasha last year with regard to that trial ?

Sir E. Grey was understood to reply that he did not see how the trial, which took place a year ago, could affect an appointment at this moment. The appointment was one which would have been made in the ordinary course, as Boutros Ghali Pasha was the senior Minister.
Mr. MacNeill : Is this the man by whose orders four Egyptians were brutally flogged 1
Sir E. Grey : The answer is in the negative. The question is one which can only be answered in the negative ; it conveys imputations on the Pasha which are entirely undeserved.
Mr. MacNeill: Did the flogging occur or not? Is that an imputafion ?
The Speaker : Order, order ' That does not arise out of the question.
THE LAMBERT AFFAIR.
A summary of the following question appeared in our special telegram of the 24th inst.:—

Mr. J.M. Robertson asked the Foreign Secretary whether his attention had been called to allegations complaining that the recent forcing ot the resignation of M. lambert, by the action of Mr. Dunlop, from the presidency of the Khedivial Law School of Egypt, was part of a persistent policy of repression and discouragement of that school and of French instruction generally, in contravention of the friendly guarantee of French educational interests which was stipulated for in 1904.

Sir E. Grey ; There is no truth whatever in the allegation that M. Lambert's resignation was forced. It was not desired at all. There is no intention whatever of not keeping the agreements of 1904 in the spirit and in the letter I with in Egypt and elsewhere.
THE EDUCATIONAL STAFF.

Mr. J. M. Robertson: Asked whether the increase recorded by Lord Cromer of over 10o per cent, in the European personnel in the Egyptian secondary schools and higher colleges in the years 1896-1906 and the decrease of 25 percent, in the Egyptian personnel in the same department in the same period were due to a falling off in the number of Egyptians educated for such posts, and if so, whether the Foreign Secretary could explain how such a falling off in the educational provision made under the supervision of the Minister of Education by the British Adviser had taken place ?

Sir Edward Grey: The demand for secondary and higher education and the development of it has been increasing more rapidly than the supply of Egyptian teachers ; measures are in hand to remedy the deficiency as far as it is possible.
QUESTION OF POSTAL RATES.

Mr. J.M. Robertson asked whether seeing that the total correspondence passing through the Egyptian Post-Office in 1906 increased to 58,000,000 as against 50,770,000 in 1905, and that since the introduction of the penny postage the correspondence exchanged between Egypt and the United Kingdom and British Colonies had increased by 60 per cent., Sir Edward Grey would now endeavour to induce the Egyptian Government toplace Egypt on an equal footing as to postal rates with the United Kingdom and the Colonies ?
Sir Edward Grey : As the penny postage already exists I do not understand to what differences the hon. member's question refers.
Mr. Robertson : Is it not the case that the postage is about one penny farthing ?
Sir E. Grey : Yes sir. It is because there is a slight difference that proceeds from the rates of exchange which it is impossible to avoid.

div.head: THE CROMER GRANT.
div.p: The Lords are expected to pass the Cromer grant without opposition. In the Commons there will be some opposition, and it is estimated that some seventy votes may be given against it. Mr. William Redmond, who objects on principle, to grants being given to officials who were well paid for their services while in office, will be supported by all the Nationalists in attendance. The Labour members and a score or more of Radicals will be on the same side. In this number, however, will not be found Mr. J. M. Robertson. Although he was a frank opponent of some aspects of Lord Cromer's policy, and although he holds that the autocratic government of Egypt is wrong, Mr. Robertson's view is that so long as we make large grants to soldiers for works of destruction, it is absurd to object to grants to civilians for useful work of construction

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Ellennan liner "Fabian" arrived in Liverpool last Sunday.
The Moss liner "Menepthak" sailed from Liverpool on Sunday last and is due here about the 11th prox. with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: THE DELINGAT INCIDENT-
div.p: TheHakimdar of the Behera Province is expected to recover from his wound, which is not dangerous.
All the brigands in whose pursuit he was shot have now been arrested and taken to Damanhonr. On the same day a fellah was shot while picking cotton :—
The following is the official version of the outrage given to a correspondent by the authorities of the moudirieh :—

The Hakimdar was shot while chasing a band of brigands, who had stolen six camels at Delingat. When the Hakimdar got up to them he ordered them to lay down their arms. They refused to comply, but left the camels and rushed off. The Hakimdar again gave chase when one of them turned and fired at him, hitting him beneath the armpit. The man who fired was at once arrested, but the others fled away. The Moudir of-the Behera Province and the Chef du Parquetcame from Damanhour to the scene of the outrage and opened an enquiry.
To tite Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir.— The state of public security in the Behera Province is going from had to worse. I have resided for several years in this part of Egypt and I can testify that the present condition of affairs was never worse than it is to-day. A few dayB ago a police officer was shot at Dagdouga. He had gone to arrest a man, but the latters' kinsmen ordered him not to. As the officer was not to be deterred from executing his duty the criminal's relations shot him dead. A few days after that a fellah was walking along the banks of the Mahmoudieh Canal, when he was attacked, murdered, and hacked to pieces, and his body thrown into the Canal. No arrests in either case have been made. On Saturday morning the Hakimdar of the Province of Behera was shot whilst on inspection duty.

The whole machinery of the Moudirieh is useless for the purposes of enforcing public security. No other province is in such a hopeless and lawless state as this is. The reason is the inefficiency of the police and the slackness of the local judges. 'It is extraordinary that the Ministry of the Interior does nothing. If things go on as at present province will be uninhabitable, as life is coming daily more and more insecure.
I am, Sir, Yours, etc.
Anglo-Egyptian.
Damanhour, 28th July.

div.head: A CRUEL VENGEANCE.
div.p: A. terriblp story of vengeance comes from Cairo, where on Sunday night a Belgian woman, Vittorine Heureux by name, 31 years of age, avenged herself against her quondam lover, Arthur Gin, by throwing a quantity of vitriol in his face. It was in Brussels that Mr. Gin lived with the woman, and when he left there he came to Cairo where he was married. Vittorine, however, followed him to Egypt, bringing with her their five year old son, and, on hearing that his wife had left for Europe, she endeavoured to persuade the man to return to her and forsake his wife. This he refused to do and at their last meeting in Boulac street the woman appeared to consent to leave him and, by paying him calls from time to time, to resume their friendship. They parted, but Vittorine called her lover back and as he drew near her, threw vitriol in his face. The man rushed along the street shouting "Au secours ' on m'a vitriols," and he was soon surrounded by a crowd, some of whom took him into a neighbouring pharmacy, where he received relief from the dreadful pain inflicted by the burning acid. Meanwhile Vittorine was approached by one of our Cairo confreres, who asked her if she had committed the crime, to which she answered "I have avenged myself; arrest me." Vittorine was then handed over to a police officer and at the caracol she expressed her pleasure at having disfigured permanently the face ot her victim and blinded one eye "so that his wife may know that I was not so contemptible." The woman was handed over to the Belgian consular authorities and has been incarcerated in the mixed prisons pending trial. Mr. Gin is 37 years of age and allowed his former mistress, who had employment at a dressmaker's, L.E. 3 per month for the expenses of their child.

div.head: THE COLONISATION SCHEME
div.p: Application was made last week in the chancery division before Mr. Justice Keke-wich by a petition, for permission to limit the sphere of operation of the Jewish Colonial Trust (Juedische Colonialbank (Ltd.). The company was formed to promote the emigration and colonisation and to advance the general welfare of the Jewish community in any part of the world. Mr. Warmington, K. C. (with Mr. Clauson) appeared on behalf of the company, who were the petitioners; Mr. Chitty represented 4,186 persons holding 40,752 shares in the company, who approved of the petition; Mr. Jesse), K. C. (with Mr. Israel), opposed the petition at the direction of a number of shareholders; and Mr. I. Zangwill appeared in person to oppose the petition.

Mr. Warmington said t&at the petition was presented by the company under the Companies Act, 1890, for the unusual purpose of restricting or abandoning some of the objects specified in the memorandum of the association. The company was formed on March 20, 1899, and it was intended to limit the < perations of the company to Palestine, Syria, parts of Turkey in Asia, the peninsula of Sinar, and the island of Cyprus. Some of the shareholders favoured the idea, but many others, including Mr. Zangwill, thought the company's operations should be unlimited. At the Zionist Congress held in the August following the establishment of the company objection was taken to the too wide powers of the company, and it was held that was not the intention of its promoters. A resolution was then passed in favour of limiting the operations of the company to the Orient, preferably Palestine and Syria. An extraordinary resolution of the company to the same effect was also passed. In 1890 the Zionist Congress passed another resolution, directing that their previous resolutions should be carried into effect, and in 1893, at a general meeting of the shareholders of the company, the directors were ordered to make the alteration for limiting th£ scope of operations. That left the governing body with no option, and on Aug. 29, 1906, a /ote of the shareholders was taken, when 4,488 Ordinary shareholders voted for and 697 against the proposal. The holders' of Founder'8 shares to the number of 8,185 voted in favour of the project. That decision was confirmed at another meeting held in September, 1906, when 4,174 Ordinary shareholders voted for the proposal and two against it, whilst the holders of Founders' shares who supported it numbered 4,176. So that there was an overwhelming majority in favour of the petition. Mr. Warmington said there had been considerable feeling amongst the shareholders, but he did not wish to say anything that would increase the friction.

Amongst the affidavits read was one by Mr. I. Zangwill, who stated that the voting was not representative or the voice of the shareholders, inasmuch at 4,488 were cast out of a total of 253,000 odd shares.
Some amusement was caused when his lordship asked if Mr. Zangwill's description as an author was a proper term in an affidavit.
Mr. Zangwill suggested it might be altered to political worker. (Laughter.)
His lordship said it was only a remark by the way.

Eventually his lordship intimated that there should be an adjournment in order that the distant shareholders, who were all over the world, should be able to express an opinion on the matter. He was very much impressed with the ultimate object of the company—to secure colonisation in Palestine, but the means to the end might be colonisation in the Argentine Republic, Africa, or elsewhere, and it might be a serious hindrance—he expressed no opinion about that—to the ultimate end to exclude those intermediate means. It was a serious question to the Jewish community, and as his lordship was not satisfied that all the shareholders had had an opportunity of considering it, he directed that there should be an adjournment until the first Tuesday in April next, and that in the meantime advertisements should be issued in the various countries concerned requesting the assent or objection of the shareholders to the proposal.

div.head: BANK CLERK'S MYSTERY.
div.p: A young man, Shirley Falcke by name, who is said by the London newspapers to hold a good position in the Anglo-Egyptian bank, has come prominently before tne public lately. The latest "Daily Telegraph" to hand gives the following:—

Details have become known of a hansom cab tragedy which occurred in the West end during the early hours of Sunday morning. A young gentleman in evening-dress named Shirley Falcke, eldest son of Mr. Falcke, a stockbroker, residing at Cromwell-mansions, Kensington, was driving in a hansom with Miss Iris Hoey, an actress, along Cromwell-road, when a pistol-shot was heard. On the cab being stopped it was found that the young man was bleeding profusely from a wound in the chest, but nis companion was uninjured On the floor of the vehicle lay a six-chambered revolver. Mr. Falcke was placed in a fourwheeler and conveyed to St. George's Hospital where last evening he was reported to be slightly better. The bullet, which lodged in his chest, had not as yet been extracted.

The young oouple had engaged the cab at the Carlton Hotel. Alter the tragedy Miss Hoey was greatly upset, and was taken to a private hotel close by. It appeara that Falcke, who holds a good position in the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, had become infatuated with the young lady in spite of the protest of his father, and when she recently went to Bedford the young man followed her. Miss Hoey lately appeared in a matinee of "Julius Caesar" at His Majesty's Theatre.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan has arrived here from Cairo.
The Princess Nazli Hanem has left London for Vichy.

During the absence of Abani Pasha, Ahmed Pasha Mazloum, Minister of Finance, will act as Minister of War, and will also represent Ibrahim Fouad Pasha as Minister of Public Instruction during the latter's absence.

It has been stated in the local press that Rear Admiral 8ir Massie Blomfield is about to retire on pension from the Director Generalship of the Porta and Lighthouses Administration. The retirement of Sir Massie Blomfield is not yet decided upori, but it is by no means improbable that he will shortly be leaving the service of the Egyptian Government, as his age—he was bom in 1835—and his long services—he became comptroller of this port in 1879—fully entitle him to a well earned repose.
Dixon Bey, Deputy Acting Director General of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration, is on a visit to Ismailia.
Lewa Jackson Pasha, C.B., Governor of the Dongola Province, has gone on leave until the 14th September.
One month's extension of leave has been grant to Lewa Hunter Pasha, D.B.O., who will return for duty on October 9.
Admiral Drury, Commander of the Mediterranean Squadron, will visit the Sultan on the 4th of August.

The Hon. Mrs. Charlee Monck and her little boy are staying at Oharieville with Visoount and Viscountess Monck. Captain the Hon. Charles Monck is expected to join them shortly on leave from Cairo, where hia regiment, the Coldstream Guards, is quartered.
Captains C. B. J. Riccardand E. A. Moles-worth, Royal Dublin Fusiliers, have returned from sick leave and resumed duty.
George Nungovich Bey has been staying during last week at the Hotel Campbell at Paris.
Mgr. Kirillos, Catholic Patriarch of Alexandria and Antioch, has arrived here from Cairo and will leave tor Sym-uhovtly.

Captain Spelterini, of the Swiss. Army, who visited Egypt last season and gave very interesting lectures in Cairo and Alexandria, has just accomplished agreatfeat He leftAndermatt in the balloon Mars, and arrived jit Bergomo, in Italy, having crossed the Alps in seven hours. This is the fitst time the Alps have been crossed in this direction.

Amongst the visitors staying at the Beau Rivage Hotel, Ramleh are : Mr. and Mrs. H. Perroth, Capt. and Mrs. H. Young, Mr. Furlanelli, Mr. and Mrs. A. Portemann and family, Mr. and Mrs. de Re and family, Mr. S. Glaudius, Mr. and Mrs. B. Davies, Mr. and Mrs. L. Haxaff, Mr. and Mrs. H, Berthy and family, Mr. and Mrs. M. Mascraft and family, Mr. and Mrs. Miller and family, Mr. L. Lim-pritis, Mr. James Watson, Mr. B. South, Mr. I. H. Mallett, Mr. C Frank, Mr. and Mrs. H. Werther, Mr. Jean Alexaki, Mr. and Mrs. B. Littledone, Mr. A Muller.

div.head: COTTON WORM.
div.p: The report of the operations against the cotton worm during the week ending 24th July is satisfactory and shows that the Interior are bringing all their forces to bear on the suppression of this pest. The figures given below illustrate very well the systematic man ner of suppression carried out by the inspectors acting under the instructions of the Ministry of the Interior and it must justly be remarked that the careful study of this question and the practical steps taken in connection with . the pest by the Government are worthy of high commendation.
The provinces of Assiout, Beni Sonef; Minieh and Keneh remained immune.
In Behera, 39,771 feddans in 253 villages were infected and 38,974 feddans cleared.
In Fayoum, 6 feddans in 2 villagee were infected and cleared.
In Gharbieh 4,060 feddans in 106 vilhges were infected and 4,055 feddans cleared. *
In Ghizeh 383 feddans in 6 villages were infected and 369 feddans cleared.
In Kalioubieh, 1,987 feddans in 6 villages were infected and cleared.
In Menoufieh, 274 feddans in 38 viDages were infected and 294 cleared, including 20 feddans infected during the preceding weak.
In Sharkia, 661 feddans in 23 villages were infected and cleared.
In Dakahlieh, 1871 feddans in 89 villages were infected and cleared.
Throughout the country 48,922 feddans in 684 villages were infected and 47,917 feddans cleared, leaving an infected area of 1,065 feddana

div.head:
MESSRS WATSON'S SOAPS.
HEAVY LIBEL DAMAGES.

div.p: The soap makers Messrs. Watson & Sons of Leeds announce that their libel aotions against the Associated Press have been settled. They will receive very heavy damages. A member of the firm informed the "Daily Chro nicies representative that they will exceed Messrs. Lever Brothers' award of £50,000. 'Pho Associated Press will publish an apology. (Reuter)

div.head:
NEW YORK PLAY-GROUND.
DESTROYED BY FIRE.

div.p: The famous Play-ground has been burned, including 20 hotels, the occupants of which escaped in their night clothes. 21 firemen have been injured. The panic was intensified by the roars of the terrified lions and tigers of Bostock's menagerie The body of one of the occupants is missing. (Reuter)

div.head:
RUSSO-JAPANESE AGREEMENT.
MAINTENANCE OF STATUS QUO.

div.p: It is understood that the Russo-Japanese agreement comprises five sections, one of which guarantees the status-quo in the Far East and assents to the new situation in Korea.
(Reuter)
The commercial agreement with Japan has been signed. (Havas)

div.head:
TURKEY AND GREECE.
THE MACEDONIAN DIFFICULTY.

div.p: The Porte has made strong representations to Greece with reference to the constant passage of armed bands across the frontier, and threatens to take vigorous measures against the Greek abet tors in Macedonia. (R.)

div.head:
THE FRENCH ELECTIONS.
HEAVY REPUBLICAN MAJORITY.

div.p: 1,411 results of the general councils elec tions are known. There have been elected 239 Conservatives, 188 Progressives, 835 Republicans of the left, 36 Socialists. There are 143 ballots. (Havas)
Mr. Clemenceau has declared to the delegates of the South that the Government is ready to take measures for restoring peace, immediately the return to lawfulness will allowit. (Havas)
Calm is restored.
The Rand strike is ended : the men are resuming work on the old terms. (Reuter)
A Russian military balloon has been picked up in the Baltic. (Reuter)

div.head: ALEXANDRIA'S FIRE BRIGADE.
div.p: Appended to the Municipality Report for the year 1906 is the report of Miralai Hopkinson Boy on the Alexandria Fire Brigade, which deserves especial notice. Under the command of Superintendent Waller this gallant brigade, whose efficiency is remarkable, has performed many acts of valour and, in the fulfilment of their grim task of combatting flames and many a time snatching their fellow beings from the jaws of an untimely death, no flinching has been seen. Always on the alert, ready to turn out and rush to the place of call in the shortest space of time, Superintendent Waller and his brave band of men have averted many a sad disaster by the promptness, willingness, and bravery with which they have worked. Alexandria may well be proud of its fire-brigade and the Municipality may congratulate itself upon having appointed Mr. Waller to drill and train it, and lead it through its fights.

Turning to the tables given at the end of Hopkinson Bey's report, we find that the force of the brigade consists of:—Chief Officer, Superintendent, Assistant Superintendent, Mo-lahez Awal, Mechanical Chauffeur, Clerk, Inspector of Theatres, 3 Engineers, 6 Chauffeurs, Sol Colghassi, Bashawish, 3 Shawish, 8 Onbashi, 77 Anfars, 12 drivers.

The equipment of the brigade is given as follows:—1 floating engine, J automobile engine, 3 steam engines, 4 hand engines, 3 hosereels, 1 salvage ladder with water tower, 3 salvage ladders, 6 scale ladders, 20 small ladders, 1 lorry for ladder, 1 barrow for coal, 9 European horses, 3 Arab horses, 1 cart, 1 Ralli car for inspection, 10 chemical cylinders, 3 smoke protecting helmets, 12,825 feet of 2 3/4 hose, 10,000 feet of 3 1/4 hose for the floating engine.

During 1906 the brigade had 121 calls, while from 1891 to 1906 the brigade answered 754 calls. The busiest month of the year was May, when there were 19 fires, and November and December come next, each with 17. The least number of fires occurred in September and October for each of which months only 4 are recorded. Out of the total for the year of 121, Attarin heads the list with 33, Menshieh comes next with 28, and then there is the considerable drop to 14 for Minet el Bassal, 13 Labban, 11 Moharrem Bey, 10 Ramleh, 7 Gumrook, and 5 Karmous.

The chief causes to which the fires have been attributed are :—the throwing away of lighted cigarette ends, 38 ; overheating ovens, 20 ; upsetting oil lamps, 15 ; want of attention with lights, 9 ; matches, 4 ; explosions, 4 ; ami children playing with fire, 4.
In concluding his report Hopkinson Bey says : —

"I desire to draw attention to the fact that Alexandria is very badly divided as regards protection against fire, and that its natural situation is probably worse than any other important town in the world; consequently, it requires a relatively higher budget. The distances to be got over are enormous, as long, if not longer, than those of no matter what brigade in the world, not excepting the London Metropolitan Fire Brigade. These distances necessitate the services of good horses, or the use of automobiles, and also the establishment of small detached posts

"The water pressure is insufficient ; in certain localities it is very feeble, or does not exist at all. This gap has to be filled up by chemical extinguishers. It is also necessary to say that the people are negligent and fatalists ; they take no precaution to prevent fire and when one breaks out they give no proof of any initiative or intelligence in making use of the means at hand to call the brigade or extinguish the fire.
"Also, the insurance companies contribute nothing towards the upkeep of the brigade.

"I cannot sufficiently emphasise the necessity of the following points:—(1) the advantages of having small posts in the banlieue equipped with a combination of apparatus containing hose and chemical extinguishers : (2) the necessity of increasing the fire pumps ; (3) the advantages accruing from alarm stations."

div.head: BUSINESS PROSPECTS IN THE SUDAN.
div.p: The following interesting article appears in the engineering supplement of the "Times."

The Sudan has been regarded by British manufacturers and merchants, ever since its reconquest, as a fresh market for the disposal of their wares ; but their ideas of the country as a field for commercial enterprise were much exaggerated owing to the lack of practical information about its condition and its possibilities—from the business man's points of view. What a manufacturer first wishes to learn in regard to a new market is whether a demand exists for the kind of goods which he makes, or what the prospect is of creating such a demand in the near future. If he is in a position to incur the risks of exporting, he then wants to know how to get into touch with possible customers of good repute, or else to find a suitable resident agent who will push the sale of his goods and keep him informed of the local requirements. Should he be unable to deal with the ramifications of the export trade, he must find a merchant who has established connections with the coveted market and persuade him to buy, or at least to introduce, his manufactures.

In any case, the requisite information is rarely to be obtained without considerable trouble and expense; and although it would be very valuable, most manufacturers are not at all disposed to pay for it They usually claim that, as taxpayers, they have the right to be provided with such information by the Foreign Office or its agents; but in so doing they overlook the fact that when information is collected by a Government department it is published for the benefit of all. In other words, they expect the State to make arrangements at the expense of the general tax payer to place them on the same level with their more capable and energetic competitors who have discovered and exploited the new market by their own efforts and at their own expense. They decline to pay the cost of pioneering yet they would like to deprive the pioneer of the reward of his entreprise. Failing the Foreign Office, they do not hesitate to appeal to the local chamber of commerce, should one exist, for information which is usually reserved for its members ; but they object to pay its fees or subscribe to the maintenance of the institution. In the case of the Sudan there is no resident British Consul to ixi worried and reviled; and its Government is too much occupied with other matters to find time to learn the business of a merchant.
Absence of Commercial Records.

The commercial development of the Sudan has indeed been very gradual, but any attempt to estimate the progress made in this direction is frustrated by the absence of proper records, the only available statistics of imports and exports prepared by the Government being extremely vague and, therefore, unsatisfactory. It would be interesting to compare the present volume of trade with that which existed before the Mahdist. rebellion, but it is impossible to do so under the prevailing circumstances. The figures published by the Government are entirely misleading, as there is no discrimination made between Government stores and general merchandise. The bulk of the imports since the reconquest has consisted of army stores, railway plant and rolling stock, machinery', implements, and other miscellaneous materials for the construction and fitting up of workshops, barracks, offices, dwelling-houses, and other Government buildings, steamers, barges, tramways, waterworks, &c.—most, if not all, have been bought by the Government for Governmental purposes. Such transactions have, therefore, no direct connection with the general trade of the country, as the Government represent both the importer and the consumer. A mere description of the articles imported and exported would be of little use to merchants or manufacturers unless they were acquainted with the difficulties of extending business into an uncivilized and but partially explored country like the Sudan. The men who have brought about the expansion of British trade in India, the Colonies, and in foreign countries have left successors who are just as enterprising as their forefathers, and, moreover, they have the superior advantage of the best modern education. They have capital and credit at their command, and are willing to undertake long expensive journeys to remote countries in order to study the means of developing fresh branches of business. Many of such men have visited Khartoum recently to inquire at first hand into the inducements offered to commercial enterprise in the Sudan but most of them have returned discouraged and disheartened—tor reasons which will be mentioned later.
The Government's Policy.
In his report for the year 1900 the Sirdar and Governor-General wrote as follows :—

The old trade of the Sudan consisted chiefly of gum, ostrich feathers, ivory, and indiarub-ber. The new trade follows much on similar lines, but the improved facilities of transport afforded by the construction of the railway to Khartum offer advantages of which the pioneers of African trade would not appear so far to have fully profited.

Thereports received from the various governors on the agricultural and commercial prospects of their respective provinces show that there is considerable scope for trade in other articles besides grain. Windmills, steam pumps, ferries, small bridges, buildings of all sorts, exploitation of forests, development of the gum trade, and many other "desiderata" immediately present themselves to the mind of

he pioneer trader, and, although every discouragement should be given to undertakings likely to bring about a "rush" into a country which is only slowly recovering from the disastrous consequences of years of misgovernment and internal chaos, nevertheless it is Astonishing to note the rapidity with which the country and the people are reviving, and I shopld be failing in my duty as local representative of Great Britain and Egypt if I did not publicly point out that there are openings — and valuable openings, too — for commerce and trade of every description in the Sudan.
In alluding to the prospects of trade with the Nile posts of Uganda and elsewhere, he remarked that:—

The paucity of steameis precludes for the present any very extensive development in this direction, nor is it in every respect, desirable that Government should undertake this trade as a permanency. On the contrary, the more private enterprise can be introduced the more advantageous will it be for all concerned.

He opened his remarks on trade by declaring that the obstacles to trade development in the Sudan were mainly due to difficulties of transport to the more remote districts, deficient irrigation, paucity of labour, and last, but not least, want of enterprise on the part of the traders.
(To be continued)

div.head: ONE GOD WORSHIP.
EGYPT ANTEDATES JEWS.
div.p: Previous ideas of ancient history and the development of religion have been revolutionized by a discovery made by the Egyptian exploration expedition of the University of Chicago and announced by the University of Chicago. Professor James H. Breasted, in charge of the party which has explored the region tributary to the Nile, has asserted that his discovery of a relief of Amenhotep IV., the monotheist Egyptian king, in a templq in Nubia proves that his sway embraced not merely the city and environs of Thebes but all of Egypt.

This discovery means that in the fourteenth century before Christ there existed a highly developed and highly civilized state, with a religion in which there was one single Supreme . God, and that the religious conceptions of the Egyptians were about 1,000 years in advance of those of the Jews.

div.head: EGYPTIAN TRADE.
div.p: The French Consul-General at Alexandria
The writes to the "Moniteur Officiel du Commerce' of 2 May on the subject of the importation of plaster of Paris into Egypt.
He mentions Cyprus, France and Turkey as the chief countries of production as shown by the following table :
He remarks that the Marseilles plaster is
classed in three qualities : White, extra superfine, per sack of 50 kilos. 40 & 4.5 francs.
White ordinary ... 30 & 33
Grey 27 & 30
Cyprus plaster sells for 18 to 19 francs the ton. Customs duties are 8% ad valorem, to which must be added 1% for wharfage dues etc.

Until 1886—1887, we are informed, this material imported into Egypt cariie exclusively from France ; but since that time factories have been started at Limassol and Larnaca which have succeeded in delivering to the Egyptian market an excellent quality of white plaster of very fine grain, the price of which is as stated above. The shipments are made in small sailing vessels at a freight charge of 5 to 7 francs per ton according to the season.

Marseilles plaster is little used in Egypt and the second quality from Marseilles is inferior to the corresponding quality from Cyprus, although costing more, doubtless owing to the difference in freight.

The manufacture of plaster in Egypt, we learn, has had some development since it was taken up by Europeans. These local plasters are largely used in building, but the third coat given should be of a gypsum other than of Egyptian origin as the produce of the country contains much saltpetre which flakes off after a little time and interferes with painting etc.

div.head: OLD MOORES' PREDICTIONS FOR 1908.
div.p: Old Moore's Almanak for 1908 has just been issued. It is as entertaining as ever to read, and it seems to contain the usual crop of doleful, hair raising, and sometimes amusing prophecies.

In January there is to be a dreadful fire in a theatre, a terrible railway disaster, and a national catastrophe near St. Paul's, London. Incidentally an attempt will be made on the life of the President of the United States, the various religious sects are to squabble over the education of the children—that seems a safe guess—and there will be a great army of unemployed doctors, for Harley-street is to be shut up and the specialists "supplanted by City Consultants at popular prices."

Death is going to reap M rich harvest in February—when doesn't he ?—and will cause a vacancy in the Cabinet; there will be the discovery of a gigantic fraud on the Government, one of Manchester's prominent citizens will suffer a brain storm, St Panl's Cathedral will be propped up, and the War Office—poor old War Office ! — will be reformed positively for the last time. Readers of society news will be interested to learn there will be a grave scandal in high life.

The War Office will get its revenge the following month, as there is going to be trouble with the Navy. "Earth current" will play havoc with our battleships, but it is comforting to know that our foreign relations will be most cordial. Death will be busy among the clergy, especially among the bishops, apparently.

April will witness exciting times in the political world, as the Opposition will indulge in "strong and bitter criticism" of two very important Government appointments! "There will be a catch or surprise vote, and the Government will be surprised, and unlucky thirteen will only just save the situation.' April is to be a particularity hatefol month, as there will be more "hum and hustle" in journalism. Impossible! . >5 ? /

Nothing much is going to happen in May, except the remarkable circumstance of an increase of Ireland's population, and June will be even quieter, as the most important event to ruin them is a campaign among women in favour of short skirts and high boots. July will be just as bad, nothing but the fall of Nelson's Column to relieve the monotony. August will usher in a bank smash and some more scandals, both society and army. A vast quantity of treasure trove will turn up in a Cathedral city.

Terrible railway accidents and steamship disasters drag their sensational way through, September; there will be more financial worries in October; you will pay more for your coal in November; and the end of the year will witness the "flowing tide of temperance submerging the beer houses."
Old Moore keeps up his form well!

div.head: COTTON SEED AS A HUMAN FOOD.
div.p: A review of the cotton seed industry, in the "U.S. Monthly Consular Reports," for June, contains some interesting facts in regard to the uses'of cotton seed. Last year 4,500,000 tons of seed were bought from the southern planters, and the sum .of 875,000,000 (=about £15,000,000) was paid to them, thus adding practically 25 per cent, to the value of the cotton crop. It is likely that a recognition of the value of the cotton-seed meal as human food will further increase the value of cotton seed. Professor J.H. Connell, of Texas, exhibited at a recent meeting of the Cotton Seed Crushers' Association at Atlanta, Georgia, samples of biscuits and cakes made from a combination of cotton-seed meal and wheat flour, which were pronounced to be delicate and testy.

For cooking purposes cotton-seed oil was, he said equal, in all respects to the best lard. By an invention of comparatively recent times, cotton seed oil could be freed from the impurities which gave it a rank odour. So-called olive oil contained a large percentage of cotton-seed oil.

div.head: £30,000 REVENUE FROM PLAYING-CARDS.
div.p: One result of the Austrian's love of gambling is the nice little sum of £30,000 which the Ministry of Finance derived last year from the tax on playing-cards. Ten manufacturers, employing 236 hands, turned out 1,578,000 packs of cards in 1906, an average of a pack for every two families in the country. These cards were of different varieties—152,000 for tarock, 765,000 for German games, 439,000 for pioket^ 107,000 whist, and 113,000 for other games, including the Italian "tressetti?' Of the total, 238,000 packs, about 15 per cent were glazed so that they could be washed. An immense number of cards were exported, chiefly to Turkey, Africa, and India.

Les personnes qui connaissent les
Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
5 fr. et 2 fr. 50

div.head: Municipalité d'Alexandrie
AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les tra- vaux d empierrement de la route de Siouf de- puis la station San Stefano a la rue El Ekbal.
Le cautionnement est fixé a LE. 70.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau de la Voirie oh il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h.a midi,les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous plî ca cheté a Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Muni cipalité avant le 14 Mars 1905.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le méme jour à 5h.p.m L'enveloppe devra porter, en outre la men- tion : "Sonmission ponr Empierrement de la Route de Siouf.
Le cautionnement qu le reçu d'une Banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis au Service de Comptabilité avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 14 mars à midi.
L'Administrateur, (Signé) W. P. Chataway Alexandrie, le 23 février 1905. 25484-3-3

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
